docs.lead_paragraph: Two new mobile health vans and a couple of support vehicles will leave from the West Side of Manhattan today on an eight-day, nine-state caravan that sponsors hope will call attention to the plight of millions of American youngsters who are not getting adequate health care. International events and the problems plaguing the Clinton Administration have taken the spotlight away from many serious issues and children's health care is one of them. There are 74 million youngsters under the age of 18 in the United States. More than 20 million do not have what advocates describe as reliable access to comprehensive health care. Eleven million are completely without health insurance.
docs.abstract: Bob Herbert Op-Ed column charges that millions of American youngsters are not getting adequate health care; cites Dr Irwin Redlener, president of Children's Health Fund, which is sponsoring an eight-state, nine-day caravan by two mobile health vans to call attention to problem, which has been pushed to the side by internatinoal events and problems plaguing Clinton Administration (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With a remote control clicker in his hand and a television monitor at his back, Mark Green, a Democratic candidate for United States Senate, whirled through campaign advertisements of one of his opponents, Charles E. Schumer, the other afternoon, disputing Mr. Schumer's claims at every frozen frame. With each pause, Mr. Green sought to demonstrate that on many issues, there was a chasm between himself and Mr. Schumer, two of the three Democrats seeking to unseat Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. On topics including regulating health maintenance organizations and assuring the future of Social Security -- issues that Mr. Schumer, Mr. Green and the third Democratic Senate candidate, Geraldine A. Ferraro, say are central to the Sept. 15 primary -- Mr. Green asserted that he held a different and more traditionally Democratic position than Mr. Schumer.

headline.main: Are Differences Big or Small? Senate Candidates Disagree

docs.abstract: New York City Public Advocate Mark Green, Democratic candidate for US Senate, says he holds different and more traditionally Democratic position than his opponent, Rep Charles E Schumer, on issues that are central to Sept 15 primary; number of Democrats question Green's assessment; Schumer says Green's attacks have been 'trivial'; actual extent of difference between Green and Schumer has emerged as ongoing dispute in otherwise subdued contest; Geraldine A Ferraro, other Democratic candidate, has kept out of this argument; Green has little money for television advertisements and has been trying to capture attention that Ferraro can take for granted and Schumer can afford to buy through advertising; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton ordered limited new rights today for people in health maintenance organizations. In his weekly radio address, Mr. Clinton said the Labor Department would require employee health plans to institute timely processes for patients to appeal denials of coverage.

headline.main: National News Briefs; Clinton Orders New Rules for H.M.O.'s

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I have another ''Wag the Dog'' scenario for Mark Katz (Op-Ed, Aug. 25). Remember that the big concept of the movie wasn't starting a war to hide a scandal; it was that it is possible to manipulate the media to determine what the American people see, how they feel and what they think. So, here's the scenario.

headline.main: Don't Blame G.O.P. for Clinton Mess

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Chinese boy is flunking out of Stuyvesant High School, staying home, talking back to voices only he can hear and punching walls. After he punches his parents, recent immigrants, they visit a psychiatrist, Qi Hu. ''If this was your son,'' Dr. Hu told me last week, ''I would be very direct, right away talking about the possibility of schizophrenia and anti-psychotic medication. But these are my people, they do not believe in mental illness, so I say: 'Your son is a genius, and he has chosen to spend his days in front of his computer, muttering to himself. So. How can I help you?''

headline.main: The Two Ways of Dr. Hu

docs.abstract: Robert Lipsyte column (Coping) on Qi Hu, Chinese psychiatrist who has opened 15-bed Asian Unit at Gracie Square Hospital in NYC; he comments on difficulties Chinese have in accepting mental health problems and solutions; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Lila Zuckerman of Bloomfield retired 10 years ago, spending time at a senior center never entered her mind. ''I didn't want to get involved. I thought old people went there,'' said Ms. Zuckerman. But she soon changed her mind. An avid theater-goer, Ms. Zuckerman first decided to take advantage of trips offered by the Marilyn Michaelson Senior Center of Bloomfield. ''That was O.K., as long as I didn't go to activities at the center. It's a game you play with yourself,'' she explained.
docs.abstract: Article on changing scene at countless senior centers across Connecticut, where focus has shifted to healthier living and more active lifestyles; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN this dog-eat-dog real-estate market, it's no surprise that dogs are having a tough time. Plenty of buildings ban dogs outright. Others impose conditions, written or unwritten: Fido rides in the freight car, Toto gets toted through the lobby, Rover requires a big security deposit, Balto had better not bark.

headline.main: Buildings Tightening the Leash on Dogs

docs.abstract: Dog policies in rental, co-op and condominium housing are tightening with current tight market; some buildings are banning dogs outright, while others impose conditions; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: DESPITE a decade of steadily rising prosperity, a million more Americans a year are losing the protective umbrella of health insurance. As a result, more than 41 million people, or 15 percent of the population, don't have coverage. They lack insured care because they can't get it at work or can't afford it. Most are adults under 65, the age when they become eligible for Medicare. Most are men. Most have no children at home, so they are ineligible for Medicaid, the insurance program for the poor. Most have jobs, or live with someone who works, but their incomes, typically below $25,000 a year, make them ineligible for Medicaid.

headline.main: The Nation; The Uninsured Find Fewer Doctors in the House

docs.abstract: Over 41 million Americans, 15 percent of population, lack health insurance; most are adults under 65; many are men with no children at home; most have jobs and incomes too high to qualify for Medicaid; charity care, last resort of uninsured, is being cut by rapid expansion of managed care; anything but emergency care is becoming harder to get in much of nation; graph of growth in number of uninsured (M)
